channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19: Tenants' advocates seek further protections
item.description: Several community organisations say tenants should not have to pay more than 30 percent of their income on rent.

item.title: Tourists hunker down rather than fly with baby
item.description: A Spanish couple say they are anxious about taking a repatriation flight with their six-month-old baby.

item.title: Covid-19 live updates from New Zealand and around the world on 26 April
item.description: A day after NZ commemorated Anzac Day, reflecting on lives lost in war, deaths worldwide from Covid-19 has passed 200,000. Follow the latest updates with RNZ's live blog here.

item.title: Employees must feel safe working at level 3 - union
item.description: Businesses re-opening next week under alert level 3 must brief staff on how they will be kept safe, the Council of Trade Unions says.

item.title: One third of early childhood centres to remain closed at level 3
item.description: One third of ECE centres will remain closed at alert level 3, the Early Childhood Council says.

item.title: Give wildlife space after lockdown ends, says DOC
item.description: People should "give nature space" when lockdown restrictions ease, the Department of Conservation says.

item.title: Film and TV actor Bruce Allpress dies aged 89
item.description: New Zealand actor Bruce Allpress has died aged 89.

item.title: Nurses complain of lack of consistency in Covid approach
item.description: Nurses warn conflicting approaches to dealing with Covid-19 between district health boards and even within hospitals are putting health workers' safety at risk.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on Anzac Day
item.description: Anzac Day was commemorated in a different way today due to the lockdown, while the Ministry of Health announced five new cases of Covid-19 and the death of a woman in her 70s.

item.title: Unemployment could reach 30% in Queenstown
item.description: Queenstown Lakes Mayor Jim Boult has laid out the "sobering, chilling" reality the district faces due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Trade Me launches charity support
item.description: Trade Me has launched a "kindness store" which aims to support charities during Covid-19.

item.title: Fat crucial to survival of right whales
item.description: New research shows New Zealand right whales are fatter and healthier than their northern counterparts, who are on the brink of extinction.

item.title: As it happened: Latest news from NZ and around the world
item.description: One third of early childhood centres say they will remain closed in level 3, while 55 percent plan to open, the Early Childhood Council says.

item.title: Victoria University students pay fee for rooms they cannot access
item.description: Victoria University is asking students to pay a placeholder fee for rooms in its halls of residence - even though some cannot return yet.

item.title: Covid-19 update 25 April: Five new cases, one death
item.description: Today there are five new cases of Covid-19 and a woman in her 70s has died.

item.title: Wellington eatery showcase to launch Monday
item.description: A new digital hub showcasing Wellington eateries has been created, with all businesses that sign up eligible to receive a subsidy of up to $500.

item.title: Young Labour camp offender to keep fighting for name suppression
item.description: The man who admitted assaulting two teenage boys at a Young Labour summer camp is set to take his fight for name suppression to the Court of Appeal.

item.title: Nearly 80 percent of Māori military personnel have PTSD symptoms
item.description: A study on serving or retired NZ military personnel has revealed alarming rates of PTSD symptoms - including 78 percent of Māori assessed.
